title: Grant v. Grant
description: The majority concludes a textile parts salesman's injuries, incurred when he was struck by a vehicle while attempting to remove an obstacle from a public road, did not arise out of and in the course of his employment.
text:
Grant v. Grant Textiles


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Charles Christopher Grant, Claimant, Respondent,
v.
Grant Textiles, Employer, and U.S. Fire Insurance Company, Carrier,
Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Spartanburg County
Â Donald W. Beatty, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3861
Heard June 8, 2004 â€“ Filed September 
  7, 2004

REVERSED


  
    
      
Steven L. Brown and Robert P. Gruber, both of Charleston, 
  for Appellants. 
Richard H. Rhodes and Ray E. Thompson, Jr., both of Spartanburg, 
  for Respondent.
      
    
  

STILWELL, J.:Â  Grant Textiles and its insurer, 
  U.S. Fire Insurance Company, appeal the circuit courtâ€™s order reversing the 
  decision of the full commission and finding Charles Grantâ€™s injuries compensable 
  under the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Act.Â  We reverse and reinstate 
  the full commissionâ€™s decision.
FACTS
Grant is the Vice-President of Grant Textiles, 
  where he is responsible for selling textile machinery parts.Â  On the day of 
  the accident, Grant drove to the Clinton House and Meeting Plantation, a private 
  hunting preserve and meeting center owned individually by him, to deliver bobbin 
  samples to customers of Grant Textiles who were staying there.Â  Grant Textiles 
  has a corporate membership at the Clinton House and, although its customers 
  are occasionally guests of the Clinton House, the company has no ownership interest 
  in the facility.Â  
As he approached the entrance gate to the Clinton 
  House, Grant and another motorist abruptly swerved to miss an object in the 
  roadway.Â  Grant testified he was concerned the object created a safety hazard 
  to guests traveling to and from the Clinton House.Â  On his arrival, Grant alerted 
  the manager of the Clinton House to the obstacle, and both men walked back down 
  the highway to attempt to remove it.Â  As Grant walked along the shoulder of 
  the road, a pickup truck swerved off the road while attempting to pass a car, 
  and struck Grant from behind.Â  As a result, he suffered bruising to the right 
  side of his body and severe injury to his right arm.Â  
The single commissioner found Grantâ€™s 
  injuries arose out of his employment with Grant Textiles and awarded compensation 
  for his claim.Â  The full commission reversed, finding Grantâ€™s accident had no 
  causal connection with his employment.Â  The full commission also found Grantâ€™s 
  ordinary job duties did not require him to remove debris from the roads and 
  his job duties and responsibilities were in no way related to road maintenance.Â  
  The circuit court reversed the full commission, concluding the injuries were 
  compensable.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
A reviewing court will not overturn a 
  decision by the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission unless the determination is 
  unsupported by substantial evidence or is affected by an error of law.Â  Dukes 
  v. Rural Metro Corp., 356 S.C. 107, 109, 587 S.E.2d 687, 688 (2003).Â  â€œSubstantial 
  evidence is evidence which, considering the record as a whole, would allow reasonable 
  minds to reach the conclusion that the administrative agency reached to justify 
  its action.â€Â  Howell v. Pacific Columbia Mills, 291 S.C. 469, 471, 354 
  S.E.2d 384, 385 (1987).Â  The question of whether an accident arises out of and 
  in the course and scope of employment is largely a question of fact for the 
  full commission.Â  Grice v. National Cash Register Co., 250 S.C. 1, 3, 
  156 S.E.2d 321, 322 (1967).Â  However, where the facts are undisputed, the question 
  of whether an accident is compensable is a question of law.Â  Gibson v. Spartanburg 
  Sch. Dist. No. 3, 338 S.C. 510, 517, 526 S.E.2d 725, 729 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  

DISCUSSION
Grant may recover workersâ€™ compensation 
  benefits only if he sustained an â€œinjury by accident arising out of and in the 
  course of the employment.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-1-160 (Supp. 2003).Â  An injury 
  arises out of oneâ€™s employment â€œwhen there is a causal connection between the 
  conditions under which the work is required to be performed and the resulting 
  injury.â€Â  Broughton v. S. of the Border, 336 S.C. 488, 497, 520 S.E.2d 
  634, 638 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  Although the injury need not be expected or even 
  foreseeable, it must appear to have originated in an employment-related risk 
  and be a rational consequence of that risk.Â  Carter v. Penney Tire & 
  Recapping Co., 261 S.C. 341, 345, 200 S.E.2d 64, 65 (1973) (citations omitted). 

Grant was a senior executive at his family-owned 
  textile supply company where he was principally involved with sales.Â  In fact, 
  according to his own testimony he would have engaged in sales activity with 
  his customers at Clinton House on the day of the accident had he not returned 
  to the highway to remove the obstacle in the road.Â  He admitted his job duties 
  and responsibilities with Grant Textiles did not include removing debris from 
  the public highway.Â  
As the sole finder of fact, the full commission 
  found that Grantâ€™s injuries did not arise out of his employment with Grant Textiles 
  because the cause of the accident had no relation to his employment duties.Â  
  â€œThe question of whether an accident arises out of and is in the course and 
  scope of employment is largely a question of fact for the Full Commission.â€Â  
  Broughton, 336 S.C. at 496, 520 S.E.2d at 638; see also 
  Gibson v. Spartanburg Sch. Dist. No. 3, 338 S.C. 510, 518, 526 S.E.2d 
  725, 729 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  
Based on that finding of fact, the full commission 
  reached the legal conclusion that Grantâ€™s accident and resulting injuries had 
  no causal connection to his employment with Grant Textiles.Â  The factual findings 
  made by the full commission are supported by substantial evidence.Â  Thus, Grantâ€™s 
  claim is not compensable as a matter of law.Â  See Douglas v. Spartan 
  Mills, 245 S.C. 265, 140 S.E.2d 173 (1965) (holding â€œan injury which cannot 
  fairly be traced to the employment as a contributing proximate cause and which 
  comes from a hazard to which [one] would have been equally exposed apart from 
  the employmentâ€ cannot be said to arise out of the claimantâ€™s employment).
We therefore conclude the trial court 
  erred in reversing the commissionâ€™s decision. Accordingly, the trial courtâ€™s 
  ruling is reversed, and the full commissionâ€™s ruling is reinstated.
REVERSED.
 CURETON, A.J., concurs.
HEARN, C.J., dissents in a separate opinion.
HEARN, C.J., dissenting:Â  I respectfully 
  dissent from the majorityâ€™s determination that Grantâ€™s injury is not compensable 
  under South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Law.Â  I would hold that Grantâ€™s injury 
  is compensable because it arose out of and in the course of his employment.Â Â Â  

The majority bases its decision largely 
  upon what it perceives to be our limited standard of review.Â  While I agree 
  that the question of whether an accident arises out of and in the course of 
  employment is largely one of fact, here there are no material facts in dispute. 
  [1] Â  Thus, the question of whether the accident is compensable is a question 
  of law.Â  See Gibson v. Spartanburg Sch. Dist. No. 3, 338 S.C. 
  510, 517, 526 S.E.2d 725, 729 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  
Despite the fact that Grant owns the Clinton House, 
  the only reason Grant drove to the Clinton House on the day of the accident 
  was to deliver sample bobbins to customers of Grant Textiles.Â  Grantâ€™s father, 
  who is the president of Grant Textiles, was already at the Clinton House meeting 
  with those customers.Â  Â 
As described in the majorityâ€™s opinion, as Grant 
  approached the Clinton House, he had to swerve out of his lane in order to avoid 
  debris in the road.Â  After successfully maneuvering around the hazard, Grant 
  left his truck idling in the entranceway of the Clinton House and walked back 
  down the highway to remove the debris from the road.Â  Although removing debris 
  from the highway was certainly not one of his regular duties as vice-president 
  of Grant Textiles, Grant explained that, on this occasion, he felt that he did 
  have an obligation to remove the hazard.Â  Specifically, Grant testified:Â Â  

[T]o me that right there was a safety issue because I had 
  to come out of the road [in order to avoid the obstacle] and ended up right 
  there at the driveway [of the Clinton House].Â  And I had some customers going 
  and coming.Â  I had some customers coming in that evening.Â  And me and my father 
  was [sic] leaving.Â  If you travel as much as I do and see some accidents, you 
  know, I thought I was doing the right thing.

By attempting to remove the debris from the road, Grant was 
  trying to ensure that the customers, his father (a co-worker), and he could 
  safely travel to and from the Clinton House.Â  
For an injury to be compensable under the South 
  Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Law, it must both arise out of and be in the 
  course of the employment.Â  Osteen v. Greenville County Sch. Dist., 333 
  S.C. 43, 49, 508 S.E.2d 21, 24 (1998).Â  The phrase â€œarising out ofâ€ refers to 
  the causal origin of the injury, whereas the phrase â€œin the course ofâ€ refers 
  to the injuryâ€™s time, place, and circumstance.Â  Id. at 50, 508 S.E.2d 
  at 24. In Hiers v. Brunson Construction Co., our supreme court explained:

â€˜[I]f in the course of [a workerâ€™s] employment an emergency 
  arises and, without deserting his employment, [the worker] does what he thinks 
  necessary for the purpose of advancing the work in which he is engaged in the 
  interest of his employer, and in so doing he suffers injury, the accident may 
  properly be regarded as arising out of the employment.â€™

221 S.C. 212, 234-235, 70 S.E.2d 211, 222 (1952) 
  (quoting 58 Am.Jur. 764).Â  Furthermore, in Osteen v. Greenville County School 
  District, 333 S.C. 43, 48, 508 S.E.2d 21, 24 (1998), the supreme court recognized 
  that our state has â€œadopted Professor Larsonâ€™s view that there are circumstances 
  when injuries arising out of acts outside the scope of an employeeâ€™s regular 
  duties may be compensable.â€Â  The court explained that â€œ[t]hese circumstances 
  have been applied to: (1) acts benefiting co-employees; (2) acts benefiting 
  customers or strangers; (3) acts benefiting claimant; and (4) acts benefiting 
  [the] employer privately.â€Â  Id. at 48-49, 508 S.E.2d at 24 (citing Larson, 
  Â§Â§ 27.00-27.48) (internal footnote omitted).Â  Â Â Â Â  
In the case before us, the undisputed 
  facts indicate that the time, place, and scope of Grantâ€™s duties as an employee 
  of Grant Textiles brought him immediately in contact with a dangerous situation. 
  The undisputed facts also show that Grant attempted to remove the debris from 
  the road in order to ensure that he, his co-employee, and the customers of Grant 
  Textiles could safely travel to and from the Clinton House.Â  Thus, Grantâ€™s injury 
  arose out of and in the course of his employment. Osteen, 333 S.C. at 
  48-49, 508 S.E.2d at 24.
The supreme courtâ€™s decision in Howell 
  v. Kash & Karry, 264 S.C. 298, 214 S.E.2d 821 (1975), lends further 
  support to awarding Grant benefits.Â  In Howell, an employee of a grocery 
  store was injured when he chased down two boys who had snatched a purse from 
  a woman in the parking lot.Â  The supreme court acknowledged that chasing thieves 
  was not part of the employeeâ€™s regular duties, but ultimately concluded the 
  employeeâ€™s injuries arose out of and in the course of his employment.Â  In reaching 
  this conclusion the court explained that â€œawards have been upheld for injuries 
  occurring in the course of miscellaneous Good Samaritan activities by employees, 
  on the theory that the employer ultimately profited as a result of the good 
  will thus created.â€Â  Id. at 301-302, 214 S.E.2d at 822.Â  Like the grocery 
  store employee in Howell, the time, place, and scope of Grantâ€™s actual 
  duties brought him immediately in contact with a situation that was dangerous 
  to his employerâ€™s customers.Â Â  While clearing debris from the highway was not 
  a part of Grantâ€™s regular duties, his attempt to rectify a dangerous situation 
  was a Good Samaritan act similar to the grocery store clerkâ€™s actions in Howell.Â  
  Therefore, I would affirm the circuit courtâ€™s decision to award Grant benefits.

 
   
    [1]  When asked during oral argument which facts were in dispute, the 
    attorney for Grant Textiles pointed to conflicting testimony concerning the 
    distance between the entrance of the Clinton House and the accident.Â  Grant 
    testified that he believed the obstacle was fifty feet down the road, but 
    â€œit may have been further.â€Â Â  The trooper from the highway patrol who investigated 
    the accident testified that â€œseeing as how both parties had left the scene, 
    [he] was not one hundred percent certain exactly where [the accident] took 
    place.â€Â  The trooper further testified that, 325 feet from the entrance of 
    the Clinton House, he found a pair of glasses on the side of the road.Â Â  While 
    the testimony from Grant and the trooper did not coincide exactly, both of 
    their descriptions indicate that the accident took place in close proximity 
    to the entrance of the Clinton House.Â  Thus, any difference in their testimony 
    is immaterial.Â  Furthermore, when this case was presented to the circuit court, 
    Grantâ€™s attorney stated twice that the facts were not in dispute, and the 
    attorney for Grant Textiles never objected to that or pointed out any facts 
    that were disputed. Â Â Â Â

title: Kizer v. Kinard
description: Verlette Kizer brought this action seeking a declaratory judgment under an UIM policy issued to her by Horace Mann Insurance Company.  The circuit court found Kizer could receive compensation for an amount up to the limits of the UIM policy subject to a setoff of $25,000.  This court affirms the circuit court's ruling.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Verlette R. Kizer, Respondent,
v.
Kenneth L. Kinard, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Bamberg County
Â Rodney A. Peeples, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3862
Heard April 7, 2004 â€“ Filed September 
  7, 2004 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Lewis C. Lanier, of Orangeburg, for Appellant.
Randolph Murdaugh, IV, of Hampton, for Respondent.
      
    
  

BEATTY, J.: Verlette R. Kizer brought this 
  action seeking a declaratory judgment under an underinsured motorist (UIM) policy 
  issued to her by Horace Mann Insurance Company.Â  The circuit court found Mrs. 
  Kizer could receive compensation for an amount up to the limits of the UIM policy 
  subject to a setoff of $25,000.Â  Horace Mann appeals, asserting it is entitled 
  to a setoff of $50,000.Â  We affirm the circuit courtâ€™s ruling.
FACTS
Verlette Kizerâ€™s claim for underinsured 
  motorist benefits arises from a collision in Bamberg County between an automobile 
  driven by her and one driven by Kenneth L. Kinard.Â  As a result of the collision, 
  Mrs. Kizer suffered severe personal injury.Â  Her husband, Charles F. Kizer, 
  also suffered damages for loss of consortium as a result of the accident; however, 
  Mr. Kizer never filed a loss of consortium action. Kinardâ€™s negligence or fault 
  in causing the accident and resulting injury and loss of consortium is not disputed 
  in this appeal.
At the time of the accident, Horace Mann 
  Insurance Company insured Mrs. Kizer against bodily injury or death caused by 
  an underinsured motorist. [1] Â  
  Kinard had automobile liability insurance coverage with Government Employees 
  Insurance Company (GEICO) with split liability limits of $50,000 per person 
  and $100,000 per occurrence.Â  
GEICO disbursed the $50,000 proceeds of 
  Kinardâ€™s liability coverage equally between Mrs. Kizer and her husband, receiving 
  a covenant not to execute from the Kizers.Â  Thus, GEICO allocated $25,000 to 
  Mrs. Kizer on her personal injury claim and $25,000 to Mr. Kizer on his loss 
  of consortium claim.Â  Claiming damages for her personal injuries in excess of 
  $25,000, Mrs. Kizer sought compensation under the Horace Mann UIM policy. [2]   
Horace Mann denied Mrs. Kizerâ€™s request, 
  asserting it was entitled to a $50,000 setoff of GEICOâ€™s policy limits against 
  all liability stemming from her personal injury claim.Â  Mrs. Kizer, however, 
  asserted Horace Mann was only entitled to a setoff of $25,000 from the GEICO 
  payments because she received that amount.Â Â  Mrs. Kizer argues that the payments 
  she and her husband received exhausted the $50,000 per person liability limits 
  of the GEICO policy.Â  The circuit court agreed with Mrs. Kizer, finding, as 
  to Mrs. Kizerâ€™s claim, that Horace Mann was entitled to a setoff of $25,000 
  of GEICOâ€™s payment. Also, the court determined that Horace Mann would be entitled 
  to a $25,000 setoff on any UIM claim by Mr. Kizer. Horace Mann appeals.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
A suit for declaratory judgment is neither legal 
  nor equitable, but is determined by the nature of the underlying issue.Â  Antley 
  v. Nobel Ins. Co., 350 S.C. 621, 625, 567 S.E.2d 872, 874 (Ct. App. 2002) 
  (citing Felts v. Richland County, 303 S.C. 354, 400 S.E.2d 781 (1991)).Â  
  As the issue below involved a determination of underinsured motorist coverage, 
  the action is at law.Â  State Farm Mut. Auto. Ins. Co. v. Calcutt, 340 
  S.C. 231, 237, 530 S.E.2d 896, 899 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  â€œIn an action at law, the 
  trial judgeâ€™s factual findings will not be disturbed on appeal unless a review 
  of the record reveals there is no evidence which reasonably supports the judgeâ€™s 
  findings.â€ Id.
LAW/ANALYSIS
Horace Mann contends it is entitled 
  to a setoff of GEICOâ€™s $50,000 policy limits in Mrs. Kizerâ€™s UIM claim because 
  Mrs. Kizer failed to exhaust GEICOâ€™s available coverage.Â  We agree that Horace 
  Mann is entitled to a setoff; the question presented on this appeal is the amount 
  of Horace Mannâ€™s setoff of GEICOâ€™s payment. 
Underinsured motorist coverage is optional 
  coverage provided when the insured sustains damages in excess of the at-fault 
  driverâ€™s liability coverage, recovery being in addition to any recovery from 
  the at-fault motorist, the total recovery not to exceed the damages sustained.Â  
  Broome v. Watts, 319 S.C. 337, 341, 461 S.E.2d 46, 48 (1995).Â  The UIM 
  statute does not require payment of the applicable policy limits as a precondition 
  to collecting UIM benefits; however, the UIM carrier is entitled to a credit 
  for any amount of liability coverage not exhausted in settlement. Cobb v. 
  Benjamin, 325 S.C. 573, 589, 482 S.E.2d 589, 597 (Ct. App. 1997).
â€œThe very definition of UIM insurance 
  mandates set-off.â€ Broome, 319 S.C. at 341, 461 S.E.2d at 48.Â  Horace 
  Mann asserts that GEICOâ€™s apportionment of payment of its policy limits between 
  Mr. and Mrs. Kizer does not alter Horace Mannâ€™s right to a setoff of the entire 
  $50,000 against any claim by Mrs. Kizer.Â  Horace Mann argues that, notwithstanding 
  payment of the liability limits of GEICOâ€™s policy, the limits were not exhausted 
  as to Mrs. Kizerâ€™s bodily injury claim because the entire amount was not paid 
  to her.Â  We disagree.
Horace Mann erroneously assumes that the 
  consequential damages characterization of a loss of consortium claim requires 
  that it be inseparable from the spouseâ€™s bodily injury claim.Â  The two claims 
  are distinct and independent.Â  â€œIt is well settled in South Carolina that one 
  spouse's cause of action for medical expenses and loss of consortium resulting 
  from negligent injuries to the other spouse is a different and distinct cause 
  of action from one maintained by the injured spouse; judgment in favor of the 
  defendant in one action is not a bar to the other action.â€ Graham v. Whitaker, 
  282 S.C. 393, 397, 321 S.E.2d 40, 43 (1984).
â€œ[A]ny person may maintain an action for damages 
  arising from an intentional or tortious violation of the right to the companionship, 
  aid, society and services of his or her spouse.â€Â  Stewart v. State Farm Mut. 
  Auto. Ins. Co., 341 S.C. 143, 156, 533 S.E.2d 597, 603-604 (Ct. App. 2000) 
  (quoting S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-75-20 (1977)).Â  â€œ[L]oss of consortium is an independent 
  action, not derivative.â€Â  Stewart, 341 S.C. at 156, 533 S.E.2d at 604. 

Our courts have decided that â€œper personâ€ 
  liability limits include loss of consortium claims. Id.; see also 
  Sheffield v. Am. Indem. Co., 245 S.C. 389, 140 S.E.2d 787 (1965).Â  However, 
  the courtsâ€™ rulings in these cases did not nullify the independent status of 
  a loss of consortium claim.Â  Nor did they rule that a loss of consortium claim 
  is inseparable from the claim of an injured spouse.Â  The courts simply pointed 
  out that the bodily injury claim and the loss of consortium claim share the 
  limits of a per person liability limits policy. 
We find that the $50,000 per person injury 
  limit in Kinardâ€™s GEICO liability policy was exhausted by the combined payment 
  of $25,000 to Mrs. Kizer for her physical injuries and $25,000 to Mr. Kizer 
  for his loss of consortium due to Mrs. Kizerâ€™s injuries.Â  Accordingly, we conclude 
  that Horace Mann is only entitled to setoff the $25,000 GEICO paid to Mrs. Kizer.Â  
  The ruling of the circuit court is therefore 
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., and ANDERSON, J., concur.

 
   [1]  Mrs. Kizer was also insured by an underinsurance 
    policy with Nationwide Insurance Company in the amount of $25,000.

 
   
    [2]  Mrs. Kizerâ€™s damages apparently amounted to at least $75,000.Â  Even 
    though Mrs. Kizer received $25,000 from GEICO and an additional $25,000 from 
    Nationwide, Horace Mann agreed to pay an additional $25,000 if Mrs. Kizer 
    prevails in this action.

title: Burgess v. Nationwide Insurance
description: In this automobile insurance case, the trial court granted declaratory relief and found Burgess was entitled to UIM coverage on a vehicle carrying basic liability coverage but no UIM coverage.  This court affirmed as modified.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Robert J. Burgess, Respondent,
v.
Nationwide Mutual Insurance Company, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Sumter County
Â Howard P. King, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3863
Heard April 6, 2004 â€“ Filed September 
  7, 2004

AFFIRMED AS MODIFIED


  
    
      
Robert C. Brown, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Kristi F. Curtis, of Sumter, and Nelson R. Parker, of Manning, for Respondent.
      
    
  

BEATTY, J.:Â Â Â Â Â Â  Robert J. Burgess brought 
  a declaratory judgment action against Nationwide Mutual Insurance Company seeking 
  a declaration that he was entitled to underinsured motorist coverage.Â  The trial 
  judge granted declaratory relief and found Burgess was entitled to UIM coverage 
  in the amount of $15,000.Â  Nationwide appeals.Â  We affirm as modified.
FACTS[1] 


Burgess
was operating his 1986 Honda motorcycle when a car driven by Angelo T. Heyward
struck him. Heyward carried automobile liability insurance on his car with New
Hampshire Indemnity Company. Burgess collected $15,000 of liability coverage
from New Hampshire Indemnity and agreed to a covenant not to execute with
Heyward. 


Burgess had a liability policy on his motorcycle with
Alpha Property and Casualty Insurance, but the policy did not provide any
underinsured motorist (â€œUIMâ€) coverage. 
In addition to the motorcycle, Burgess also owned three vehicles that
were covered by Nationwide Mutual Insurance Company (â€œNationwideâ€). That
policy provided UIM coverage of $25,000 per person. The Uninsured and
Underinsured Motorist Endorsement provided that: 


If a vehicle owned by you or a relative is involved in
an accident where you or a relative sustains bodily injury or property damage,
this policy shall:  a) be primary if
the involved vehicle is your auto described on this policy; or b) be excess if
the involved vehicle is not your auto described on this policy.  The amount of coverage applicable under this policy shall be
the lesser of the coverage limits under this policy or the coverage limits on
the vehicle involved in the accident. 
  Because the motorcycle was not listed under Nationwideâ€™s 
    policy, Nationwide refused to pay Burgess, arguing that the motorcycle did 
    not have any UIM coverage. 
  Burgess moved for declaratory judgment. He argued 
    that he was entitled to $15,000 of UIM coverage from the Nationwide policy 
    that covered his â€œat-homeâ€ vehicles. Nationwide countered it should not be 
    required to pay any UIM benefits because Burgess had more than the basic amount 
    of UIM coverage and the vehicle involved in the accident had none. Nationwide 
    also argued that its UM/UIM endorsement excludes coverage under these circumstances. 
    The trial judge granted declaratory relief to Burgess in the amount of $15,000. 
  
  ISSUES

  
    
      
          I.   
         
    Did the trial court err in finding Burgess was entitled to UIM coverage in 
    an amount equal to the liability coverage on the Honda motorcycle involved 
    in the accident under the Nationwide policy?
      
      
         II.
        Did the trial court err in finding that Burgess was entitled to UIM coverage 
    under S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 38-77-160?
      
      
         III.  
         
    Did the trial court err in finding that Burgess was entitled to coverage under 
    Nationwideâ€™s policy?
      
    
  

STANDARD OF REVIEW
   Whether a suit for declaratory judgment 
      is legal or equitable is determined by the nature of the underlying issue. 
      Auto-Owners Ins. Co. v. Horne, 356 S.C. 52, 56, 586 S.E.2d 865, 867 
      (Ct. App. 2003) (citing Felts v. Richland County, 303 S.C. 354, 356, 
      400 S.E.2d 781, 782 (1991)). â€œAn action to determine coverage under an insurance 
      policy is an action at law.â€ S.C. Farm Bureau Mut. Ins. Co. v. Wilson, 
      344 S.C. 525, 528, 544 S.E.2d 848, 849 (Ct. App. 2001). In an action at 
      law, tried without a jury, the appellate court will not disturb the trial 
      court's findings of fact unless they are found to be without evidence that 
      reasonably supports those findings.Â  Townes Assocs., Ltd. v. City of 
      Greenville, 266 S.C. 81, 86, 221 S.E.2d 773, 775 (1976).Â  However, when 
      an appeal involves stipulated or undisputed facts, an appellate court is 
      free to review whether the trial court properly applied the law to those 
      facts.Â  In re Estate of Boynton, 
      355 S.C. 299, 301, 584 S.E.2d 154, 155 (Ct. App. 2003). In such a situation, 
      the appellate court does not have to defer to the trial courtâ€™s findings.Â  
      Id. 
   LAW/ANALYSIS
    There is a great 
      division of authority as to coverage for damages arising out of accidents 
      involving owned but not insured vehicles.Â  In some jurisdictions, UIM coverage 
      follows the person; in others it follows the vehicle.Â  We believe that South 
      Carolina falls in the category where UIM coverage follows the person, as 
      is the case with uninsured motorist (â€œUMâ€) coverage.
    UIM insurance is a variant of UM insurance.Â  
      9 Couch on Ins. 3d Â§ 122:3 (2004).Â  In some jurisdictions, UIM is 
      referred to as supplemental uninsured coverage.Â  Id.Â  South Carolina 
      courts have often analogized UM and UIM, especially when discussing the 
      application and interpretation of section 38-77-160 of the South Carolina 
      Code (2002), which deals with UM and UIM coverage. 
      [2]  Therefore, our appellate courtsâ€™ treatment of UM is instructive 
      in this case. 
    The purpose of the UM statute is â€œto provide benefits 
      and protection against the peril of injury or death by an uninsured motorist 
      to an insured motorist, his family, and the permissive users of his vehicle.â€ 
      Ferguson v. State Farm Mut. Auto Ins. Co., 261 S.C. 96, 100, 198 
      S.E. 2d 522, 524 (1973).Â  The statute â€œis remedial in nature, enacted for 
      the benefit of injured persons, and is to be liberally construed so that 
      the purpose intended may be accomplished.â€ Gunnels v. American Liberty 
      Ins. Co., 251 S.C. 242, 247, 161 S.E.2d 822, 824 (1968).
    Our supreme court has previously explained, 
      â€œuninsured motorist coverage is not to provide coverage for the uninsured 
      vehicle but to afford additional protection to the insured.â€Â  Nationwide 
      Mut. Ins. Co. v. Howard, 288 S.C. 5, 12, 339 S.E.2d 501, 504 (citing 
      Hogan v. Home Ins. Co., 260 S.C. 157, 162, 194 S.E.2d 890, 892 (1973)).Â  
      The court further clarified in Hogan that â€œunlike the provisions 
      relative to liability coverage, the statute plainly affords uninsured motorist 
      coverage to the named insured and resident relatives of his or her household 
      at all times and without regard to the activity in which they were engaged 
      at the time.Â  Such coverage is nowhere limited in the statute to the use 
      of the insured vehicle.â€Â  Hogan, 260 S.C. at 162, 194 S.E.2d at 892. 
    
    Similarly, the statutory purpose of UIM coverage 
      is to provide coverage in the event damages are sustained in excess of the 
      liability limits carried by an at-fault insured or underinsured. S.C.Code 
      Ann. Â§ 38-77-160.Â  Thus, our UIM statute is also remedial in nature and 
      enacted for the benefit of injured persons. It should be construed liberally 
      to effect the purpose intended by the legislature. See Sloan v. 
      Greenville County, 356 S.C. 531, 564, 590 S.E.2d 338, 356 (Ct. App. 
      2003) (reasoning that the provisions of a code should be construed liberally 
      if the code is remedial in nature).
    
    Understanding that 
      UIM coverage is a variation of UM coverage, we believe that Hogan 
      indicates the legislative intent behind our UIM statute and is applicable 
      here. In other words, underinsurance, like uninsurance, is 
      personal and portable.Â  â€œIn jurisdictions where the coverage follows the 
      person any person who enjoys the status of an insured under a motor vehicle 
      policy of insurance which includes uninsured/underinsured coverage enjoys 
      coverage protection simply by reason of having been injured by an uninsured/underinsured 
      motorist.â€ 9 Couch on Ins. 3d Â§ 123:3. [3] 
    S.C. Code 
      Ann. Â§ 38-77-160
    The proper interpretation 
      of section 38-77-160 is central to the resolution of the issues in this 
      case.Â  That section deals with UM and UIM and states:Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 

    Automobile insurance carriers 
      shall offer, at the option of the insured, uninsured motorist coverage up 
      to the limits of the insuredâ€™s liability coverage in addition to the mandatory 
      coverage prescribed by section 38-77-160.Â  Such carriers shall also offer, 
      at the option of the insured, underinsured motorist coverage up to the limits 
      of the insured liability coverage to provide coverage in the event that 
      damages are sustained in excess of the liability limits carried by an at-fault 
      insured or underinsured motorist or in excess of any damages cap or limitation 
      imposed by statute.Â  If, however, an insured or named insured is protected 
      by uninsured or underinsured motorist coverage in excess of the basic limits, 
      the policy shall provide that the insured or named insured is protected 
      only to the extent of the coverage he has on the vehicle involved 
      in the accident. Â If none of the insuredâ€™s or named insuredâ€™s vehicles 
      is involved in the accident, coverage is available only to the extent of 
      coverage on any one of the vehicles with the excess or underinsured coverage. 
       [4]   

    (Emphasis added).
    Nationwide argues 
      that the emphasized language excludes basic UIM coverage in situations where 
      the vehicle involved in a collision is owned by the insured but is not specifically 
      covered in a UIM policy.Â  We disagree.Â  
    The emphasized language has 
      been interpreted or discussed on numerous occasions by our appellate courts. 
      [5] Â  Several of those cases involved facts very analogous to the case 
      sub-judice. [6] Â  However, none of them has directly 
      addressed the question we face today, that is whether or not section 38-77-160 
      and public policy allow the exclusion of basic UIM coverage.Â  Each of the 
      cases addressed the issue of â€œstackingâ€ UIM or UM coverage.Â  Invariably, 
      each of these cases found the emphasized language to apply to situations 
      involving stacking.Â  See S.C. Farm Bureau Mut. Ins. Co. v. Mooneyham, 
      304 S.C. 442, 445, 405 S.E.2d 396, 398 (1991) (â€œ[W]e interpret the pertinent 
      language of the statutes as setting a cap on the amount which can be stacked 
      . . . .â€).Â  In each case the insurer made an initial payment of at least 
      the basic UIM/UM coverage and only litigated additional UIM/UM payments.Â  
    
    To address the issue of basic 
      coverage, we must consider section 38-77-160 in its entirety, not just the 
      isolated emphasized portion argued by Nationwide.Â  See Beattie 
      v. Aiken County Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs., 319 S.C. 449, 452, 462 S.E.2d 
      276, 278 (1995) (â€œAn entire code section should be read as a whole so that 
      phraseology of isolated section is not controlling.â€). Additionally, â€œ[o]ne 
      of the primary rules in a construction of a statute is that the words used 
      therein should be taken in the ordinary and popular significance, unless 
      there is something in the statute requiring a different interpretation.â€ 
      Gambrell, 280 S.C. at 73, 310 S.E.2d at 817.Â  A subtle or forced 
      construction of words in a statute for the purpose of expanding the operation 
      of the statute is prohibited.Â  See Moon v. City of Greer, 
      348 S.C. 184, 188, 558 S.E.2d 527, 530 (Ct. App. 2002).Â Â  
    Section 38-77-160 states in 
      pertinent part:

  
    
      
         Such carriers shall also offer, at the option of the insured, 
      underinsured motorist coverage up to the limits of the insured liability 
      coverage to provide coverage in the event that damages are sustained 
      in excess of the liability limits carried by an at-fault insured 
      or underinsured motorist or in excess of any damages cap or limitation imposed 
      by statute . . . .Â  If none of the insuredâ€™s or named insuredâ€™s vehicles 
      is involved in the accident, coverage is available only to the extent of 
      coverage on any one of the vehicles with the excess or underinsured coverage.
      
    
  

     Nowhere in the statute 
      is there language that limits basic UIM coverage to an insured vehicle.Â  
      To the contrary, the statute plainly allows coverage when none of the insuredâ€™s 
      vehicles is involved in the accident.Â  To say that the legislative intent 
      was to exclude basic UIM coverage if an insuredâ€™s vehicle is involved in 
      an accident but include coverage when none of the insuredâ€™s vehicles is 
      involved in an accident is absurd, absent specific language to that effect.Â  
      In construing a statute, the court looks to its language as a whole in light 
      of its manifest purpose.Â  Simmons v. City of Columbia, 280 S.C. 163, 
      165, 311 S.E.2d 732, 733 (1984).Â  The manifest purpose of section 38-77-160 
      is to provide coverage in the event that the insured sustains damages in 
      excess of the liability limits carried by the at fault motorist. 
    Nationwideâ€™s argument that 
      the emphasized language of section 38-77-160 excludes coverage because Burgess 
      had no UIM coverage on the motorcycle is without merit based upon our finding 
      that UIM coverage is personal and portable.Â  Moreover, our supreme court 
      said in Howard, when construing the emphasized provision of 56-9-831 
      as it pertains to UM coverage, that such coverage was nowhere limited to 
      the use of the insured vehicle. 
      [7] Â  That holding is instructive here.
    Nationwide also argues that 
      since Burgessâ€™s UIM coverage exceeded the basic UIM coverage of $15,000, 
      his coverage is excess and therefore his claim is precluded by the emphasized 
      language in section 38-77-160. 
      [8] Â  However, section 38-77-160 does not limit basic UIM in 
      any way; all limitations specifically reference excess UIM. Had the 
      legislature intended to limit basic UIM coverage, it could have easily done 
      so by simply omitting the word â€œexcess.â€Â  To argue that Burgess should be 
      denied UIM coverage because he purchased too much is absurd.
    Â Â  UIM Policy 
      Endorsement  
    Nationwide next argues 
      that its UIM endorsement precludes Burgessâ€™sÂ Â Â  recovery of UIM benefits 
      because the motorcycle had no UIM coverage.Â  Nationwideâ€™s endorsement states, 
      in pertinent part, â€œ[t]he amount of coverage applicable under this policy 
      shall be the lesser of the coverage limits under this policy or the coverage 
      limits on the vehicle involved in the accident.â€
    Nationwideâ€™s endorsement 
      language is far more restrictive than the language in section 38-77-160.Â  
      Nationwide excludes the recovery of basic UIM whereas section 38-77-160 
      merely allows an insurer to limit the amount of recovery of excess UIM.Â  
      The statute does not allow an insurer to limit or exclude basic UIM in any 
      way.Â  An insurance policy issued pursuant to a statute may give more coverage 
      than the statute requires but not less.Â  Belk v. Nationwide Mut. Ins. 
      Co., 271 S.C. 24, 244 S.E.2d 744 (1978).Â  Once UIM is offered and accepted, 
      the coverage cannot be retracted. See Gambrell v. Travelers Ins. 
      Co., 280 S.C. 69, 72, 310 S.E.2d 814, 816 (1983). 
    Section 
      38-77-160 governs the application of UIM coverage. It applies to every policy 
      as if embodied therein, and inconsistent insurance policy provisions are 
      void.Â  State Farm Mut. Ins. Co. v. Gunning, 340 S.C. 526, 532 S.E.2d 
      16 (2000). Nationwideâ€™s endorsement exceeds the limitations allowed by section 
      38-77-160 and is therefore inconsistent with our public policy.Â  
    Moreover, in State 
      Farm Mut. Ins. Co. v. Horry, 304 S.C. 165, 403 S.E.2d 318 (1991), our 
      supreme court expressly approved this courtâ€™s opinion in Purvis v. State 
      Farm Mut. Ins. Co., 302 S.C. 283, 403 S.E.2d 662 (Ct. App. 1991) which 
      declared South Carolina to be an â€œexcessâ€ UIM coverage state.Â  The court 
      went on to say that â€œexcessâ€ UIM coverage â€œprovides benefits to an insured 
      under his own policy at any time the at fault drivers liability coverage 
      is less than the amount of the claimants actual damages.â€Â  Horry, 
      304 S.C. at 169, 403 S.E.2d at 320 (emphasis added). 
      [9] Â  The court did not require that the vehicle involved in the accident 
      carry UIM coverage.                                                     
    CONCLUSION
    The trial court erred when it concluded 
      that Burgess was entitled to $15,000 UIM coverage from the at home vehicles 
      because he had $15,000 liability coverage on the motorcycle involved in 
      the accident. Burgess was entitled to $15,000 UIM coverage because that 
      is the statutory minimum coverage and Burgess had at least that amount on 
      the at home vehicles. However, because we find that UIM coverage is personal 
      and portable, and because we find that section 38-77-160 does not allow 
      the exclusion or restriction of basic UIM coverage, we affirm the trial 
      courtâ€™s decision as modified.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
     AFFIRMED AS MODIFIED.
    HEARN, C.J., and ANDERSON, J., concur. 

 
   [1]  The parties stipulate these facts. 

 
   [2]  See McAllister v. State Farm Mut. Auto 
    Ins. Co., 301 S.C. 113, 390 S.E.2d 383 (1990); Nationwide Mut. Ins. 
    Co. v. Howard, 288 S.C. 5, 339 S.E.2d 501 (1985).

 
   
    [3]  South Carolina appears to share the majority view.Â  See DeHerrera 
    v. Sentry Ins. Co. 30 P.3d 167 (Colo. 2001); Honeycutt v. Walker, 
    119 N.C. App. 220, 458 S.E. 2d 23 (1995) review denied, 342 N.C. 192, 
    463 S.E.2d 236 (1995); Dines v. Pacific Ins. Co., 78 Haw. 325, 893 
    P.2d 176 (1995), recons. denied, 78 Haw. 474, 896 P.2d 930 (1995); 
    Smith v. Nationwide Mut. Ins. Co., 328 N.C. 139, 400 S.E.2d 44 (1991), 
    rehâ€™g denied, 328 N.C. 577, 403 S.E. 2d 514 (1991); Howell v. Balboa 
    Ins. Co., 564 So.2d 298 (La. 1990); see also State Farm 
    Mut. Auto Ins. Co. v. Jackson, 462 So.2d 346 (Ala. 1984), later proceeding, 
    757 F.2d 1220 (11th Cir. Ala. 1985). 

 
   [4] Â Â  There is no requirement that an insurer offer 
    UIM coverage in an amount less than the statutorily required bodily injury 
    or property damage limits. S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 38-73-470 (Supp. 2002); Moody 
    v. Dairyland, 354 S.C. 28, 28, 579 S.E.2d 527, 529 (Ct. App. 2003). The 
    statutorily required minimum bodily injury amount is $15,000. See S.C. 
    Code Ann. Â§ 38-77-140 (Supp.2002).

 
   
    [5]  See Concrete Services v. U.S. Fidelity, 331 S.C. 506, 
    498 S.E.2d 865 (1998); South Carolina Farm Bureau Mut. Ins. Co. v. Mooneyham, 
    304 S.C. 442, 405 S.E.2d 396 (1991); Howard; Garris v. Cincinatti 
    Ins. Co., 280 S.C. 149, 311 S.E.2d (1984); Gambrell v. Travelers Ins. 
    Co., 280 S.C. 69, 310 S.E.2d 814 (1983); State Farm Mut. Ins. Co. v. 
    Gunning, 304 S.C. 526, 532 S.E.2d 16 (Ct. App. 2000); Ohio Cas. Ins. 
    Co. v. Hill, 323 S.C. 208, 473 S.E.2d 843 (Ct. App. 1996).

 
   
    [6] Â  See McAlister; Gunning; Continental Ins. 
    Co. v. Shives, 328 S.C. 470, 492 S.E.2d 808 (Ct. App. 1997); Hill.

 
   
    [7]  Section 56-9-831 was the predecessor to section 38-77-160.Â  Although 
    the section has been amended and recodified as section 38-77-160, the pertinent 
    emphasized language is unchanged.

 
   
    [8]  Nationwide offers no authority in support of its position.Â  Nationwide 
    concedes that South Carolinaâ€™s reported cases with similar facts are not directly 
    on point but argues the inferences from those cases supports its position.Â  
    Again, each of the cases raised by Nationwide concerns stacking.

 
   [9]  The phrase â€œexcess UIM coverageâ€ as used in Horry 
    is not synonymous with the word â€œexcessâ€ as used in Â§ 38-77-160. In Â§ 38-77-160 
    the word excess refers to an amount of coverage greater than the basic amount 
    of $15,000. In Horry the phrase refers to a type of underinsurance 
    coverage theory, i.e., â€œ excess UIMâ€ or â€œ reduction UIM.â€

description: Appellant appeals his convictions for murder and possession of a weapon during the commission of a crime of violence. text:
Â THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Levell Weaver, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Williamsburg County
Â Howard P. King, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3864
Heard June 9, 2004 â€“ Filed September 
  7, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Robert M. Dudek, of Columbia, 
  for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, 
  and Assistant Attorney General Derrick K. McFarland, all of Columbia; and Solicitor 
  Cecil Kelley Jackson, of Sumter, for Respondent.
      
    
  

CURETON, A.J.:Â  Levell Weaver appeals his 
  convictions for murder and possession of a weapon during the commission of a 
  crime of violence. Weaver contends the trial court erred in:Â  (1) admitting 
  evidence obtained pursuant to a procedurally defective warrant; (2) admitting 
  hearsay testimony; and (3) declining to grant a mistrial based on inappropriate 
  prosecutorial comment on Weaverâ€™s decision not to testify during the trial.Â  
  We affirm.
FACTS
At approximately 10:00 p.m. on June 23, 1999, Marion 
  Dwayne McKnight was shot thirteen times while outside a club called Robâ€™s Place 
  in Hemingway, South Carolina.Â  At the time of the shooting, McKnight was getting 
  into his car with Antonio Brown and Tracy Scott. Â After the shooting, 
  Scott contacted his mother, Loretta, who drove to the club.Â  When she arrived 
  she saw Weaver covered in blood, standing over McKnightâ€™s body that had been 
  stripped to its underwear. 
Investigator Sandy Thompson, with the Williamsburg 
  County Sheriffâ€™s Department, was called around 11:00 p.m. to investigate the 
  incident.Â  Leroy Powell, who witnessed the shooting, identified Weaver as the 
  shooter.Â  Investigator Thompson interviewed other witnesses and spoke with investigators 
  at the scene who informed him that Weaver was a suspect and that he left the 
  scene driving a green Jeep. Â Upon further investigation, the officers 
  discovered that Weaver was at his cousinâ€™s house.Â  Investigator Thompson then 
  left for the residence accompanied by Investigator Collins and several other 
  officers.Â  At the home, the officers spoke with Weaverâ€™s cousin, Arnold Weaver.Â  
  He confirmed Weaver arrived driving a green Jeep and told them Weaver had asked 
  for bleach, a trash bag, and a change of clothes.Â  Â Â 
After the discussion with Weaverâ€™s cousin, officers 
  found the Jeep in the backyard.Â  When Investigator Thompson opened the driverâ€™s 
  side door, he noticed the Jeepâ€™s back area was wet and smelled of bleach.Â  On 
  a pump house near the Jeep, Investigator Thompson also discovered a bag containing 
  a towel and some socks which smelled of bleach.Â  To preserve the evidence for 
  investigation, the officers seized the bag and towed the Jeep to an impoundment 
  area. Â During the early morning hours of June 24, 1999, Weaver turned 
  himself in at the Williamsburg County Jail.Â  
After the Jeep was impounded, Lieutenant Ricky 
  Weston requested and obtained a search warrant.Â  Though the police searched 
  the impounded vehicle after the warrant was issued, no return of the warrant 
  was made. 
SLED Agent Steve Lambert processed the vehicle 
  and collected samples of blood evidence from the Jeep and the decedentâ€™s vehicle.Â  
  During the search, Agent Lambert found a cloth with blood evidence on the back 
  seat of the Jeep. As part of the investigation, Lambert analyzed a pair of underwear 
  that contained blood evidence.Â  Agent Lambert received this evidence from Investigator 
  Dennis Parrott who identified the underwear as belonging to Weaver.Â  Investigator 
  Parrott also turned over the bag of clothing that was seized from the pump house 
  near the Jeep. Â DNA testing of the evidence revealed that all of the 
  samples matched the decedentâ€™s blood type.
A Williamsburg County grand jury indicted Weaver 
  for murder, armed robbery, and possession of a weapon during a violent crime.Â  
  Before trial, Weaverâ€™s counsel filed a motion to suppress evidence taken from 
  the Jeep on two primary grounds:Â  (1) the Jeep was seized without a warrant; 
  and (2) no return was made to the search warrant as required by South Carolina 
  Code section 17-13-140.Â  The trial court made a preliminary ruling denying the 
  motion to suppress.Â Â  
During trial, Weaverâ€™s counsel renewed his motion.Â  
  After hearing testimony and arguments, the court gave a final ruling denying 
  the motion to suppress. Â As a threshold matter, the court found Weaver 
  had standing to challenge the legitimacy of the search even though he was not 
  the owner of the vehicle.Â  The court then concluded a search warrant was not 
  necessary because the State had probable cause to seize the vehicle and to conduct 
  the subsequent search.Â  The court reasoned the warrantless search was permissible 
  based on the automobile exception to the Fourth Amendment.Â  As a result, 
  the court found an analysis of the statutory provisions of section 17-13-140 
  was unnecessary.
The jury found Weaver guilty of murder and possession 
  of a weapon during the commission of a crime of violence.Â  The trial court sentenced 
  Weaver to thirty years imprisonment for murder and a concurrent five-year sentence 
  for the weapon charge.Â Â  This appeal follows.
DISCUSSION
I.
Weaver contends the trial court erred in denying 
  his motion to suppress the evidence seized from the Jeep. Â Specifically, he 
  asserts the court erred in finding that a search warrant was not necessary.Â  
  Moreover, because a warrant was required, Weaver claims the failure to file 
  a return as mandated by section 17-13-140 invalidated the search, and thus, 
  required the suppression of the evidence.
â€œOn appeal from a suppression hearing, this court 
  is bound by the circuit courtâ€™s factual findings if any evidence supports the 
  findings.â€ State v. Abdullah, 357 S.C. 344, 349, 592 S.E.2d 344, 347 
  (Ct. App. 2004).Â  â€œIn an appeal from a motion to suppress evidence based on 
  Fourth Amendment grounds, an appellate court may conduct its own review of the 
  record to determine whether the evidence supports the circuit courtâ€™s decision.â€Â  
  Id. at 349-50, 592 S.E.2d at 347.Â  
Section 17-13-140 requires search warrants to be 
  executed and return made within ten days after the date of the warrant:

Any warrant issued hereunder shall be executed and return 
  made only within ten days after it is dated. The officer executing the warrant 
  shall make and deliver a signed inventory of any articles seized by virtue of 
  the warrant, which shall be delivered to the judicial officer to whom the return 
  is to be made, and if a copy of the inventory is demanded by the person from 
  whose person or premises the property is taken, a copy of the inventory shall 
  be delivered to him.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-13-140 (2003).
Failure to observe the ten-day requirement for 
  execution and return under section 17-13-140 does not necessarily void the warrant.Â  
  State v. Wise, 272 S.C. 384, 386, 252 S.E.2d 294, 295 (1979) (holding 
  the ten-day requirement was ministerial and the defendant failed to show he 
  was prejudiced by the delay).Â  Because the statuteâ€™s return requirement is ministerial 
  in nature, any purported noncompliance only provides grounds for exclusion upon 
  a showing of prejudice.Â  State v. Mollison, 319 S.C. 41, 47, 459 S.E.2d 
  88, 92 (Ct. App. 1995).Â  In at least one case, this court has excluded evidence 
  based on the provisions of section 17-13-140. State v. Freeman, 319 S.C. 
  110, 459 S.E.2d 867 (Ct. App. 1995).Â  In Freeman, we found that drug 
  evidence should have been excluded under a defective warrant where the State 
  failed to produce the original warrant and a signed, sworn return.Â  We concluded 
  the defendant was prejudiced by this failure given he was unable to review the 
  return and match the items listed with the items that were analyzed and admitted 
  into evidence.Â  Id. at 116-19, 459 S.E.2d at 871-72.
Here, the police searched and seized the 
  Jeep prior to obtaining the warrant that Weaver contends was rendered faulty 
  by virtue of noncompliance with the statuteâ€™s return requirement.Â  We agree 
  with Weaver that the Stateâ€™s failure to produce a return constituted more than 
  a ministerial error.Â  However, as will be discussed, any error in failing to 
  file a return did not require the suppression of the evidence.Â  Under the specific 
  facts of this case, a warrant was not necessary to search and seize the Jeep. 

The Fourth Amendment guarantees â€œ[t]he 
  right of the people to be secure . . . [from] unreasonable searches and seizures.â€ 
  U.S. Const. amend. IV.Â  â€œIn parallel with the protection of the Fourth Amendment, 
  the South Carolina Constitution also provides a safeguard against unlawful searches 
  and seizures.â€Â  State v. Forrester, 343 S.C. 637, 643, 541 S.E.2d 837, 
  840 (2001); S.C. Const. art. I, Â§ 10.Â  Evidence obtained in violation of the 
  Fourth Amendment is inadmissible in both state and federal court. Forrester, 
  343 S.C. at 643, 541 S.E.2d at 840.
â€œGenerally, a warrantless search is per se unreasonable 
  and thus violative of the Fourth Amendmentâ€™s prohibition against unreasonable 
  searches and seizures.â€ State v. Bultron, 318 S.C. 323, 331, 457 S.E.2d 
  616, 621 (Ct. App. 1995).Â  â€œHowever, a warrantless search will withstand constitutional 
  scrutiny where the search falls within one of a few specifically established 
  and well delineated exceptions to the Fourth Amendment exclusionary rule.â€ Id. 
  at 331-32, 457 S.E.2d at 621.Â  These exceptions include:Â  (1) search incident 
  to a lawful arrest;Â  (2) â€œhot pursuit;â€Â  (3) stop and frisk;Â  (4) automobile 
  exception;Â  (5) â€œplain viewâ€ doctrine;Â  (6) consent; and (7) abandonment.Â  State 
  v. Dupree, 319 S.C. 454, 456-57, 462 S.E.2d 279, 281 (1995), cert. denied, 
  516 U.S. 1131 (1996). Â â€œThe burden of establishing probable cause as well as 
  the existence of circumstances constituting an exception to the general prohibition 
  against warrantless searches and seizures is upon the prosecution.â€Â  Bultron, 
  318 S.C. at 332, 457 S.E.2d at 621.
Our supreme court analyzed the automobile exception 
  in State v. Cox, 290 S.C. 489, 351 S.E.2d 570 (1986).Â  In Cox, 
  the court stated:

The automobile exception was first articulated in Carroll 
  v. United States, 267 U.S. 132, 45 S. Ct. 280, 69 L. Ed. 543 (1925).Â  Since 
  Carroll, the doctrine has been applied on a case-by-case basis to various 
  sets of facts.Â  
The two bases for the exception are:Â  (1) the ready mobility 
  of automobiles and the potential that evidence may be lost before a warrant 
  is obtained; and (2) the lessened expectation of privacy in motor vehicles which 
  are subject to governmental regulation.

Id. at 491, 351 S.E.2d at 571 (citations 
  omitted).Â  In view of these reasons, the court found that â€œunder the automobile 
  exception, probable cause alone is sufficient to justify a warrantless 
  search.â€Â  Id. at 492, 351 S.E.2d at 571-72 (citing California v. Carney, 
  471 U.S. 386 (1985)).Â  Thus, â€œthe inherent mobility of automobiles provides 
  the requisite exigency.â€Â  Id. at 492, 351 S.E.2d at 572. 
In this case, the State met its burden to prove 
  probable cause and the existence of circumstances to support the warrantless 
  search under the automobile exception.Â  During their investigation at the crime 
  scene, the officers established that:Â  (1) Weaver was a suspect; (2) he had 
  been seen driving a green Jeep; and (3) there most likely would be blood evidence 
  in the Jeep if in fact Weaver had been involved in the shooting.Â  Additionally, 
  once the officers arrived at Weaverâ€™s cousinâ€™s home, they discovered that Weaver 
  had asked for a change of clothing, a trash bag, and bleach.Â  Upon further investigation, 
  the officers found a bag of â€œwash clothesâ€ near the Jeep that smelled of bleach 
  and the inside of the Jeep was wet with bleach.Â  Thus, based on probable cause 
  that the automobile contained evidence of a crime, and the necessity to preserve 
  the potential blood evidence, the warrantless search and subsequent seizure 
  did not violate the Fourth Amendment. See Cox, 290 S.C. at 492, 
  351 S.E.2d at 572 (holding automobile exception applied to shotgun seized from 
  trunk of vehicle parked at defendantâ€™s home); State v. Peters, 271 S.C. 
  498, 501, 248 S.E.2d 475, 477 (1978) (finding probable cause existed to conduct 
  warrantless search of vehicle based on Carroll doctrine where police 
  stopped vehicle after receiving information from confidential informant that 
  defendant was driving vehicle containing marijuana); State v. Hayden, 
  268 S.C. 214, 218, 232 S.E.2d 889, 891 (1977) (holding probable cause and exigent 
  circumstances justified warrantless search of automobile where officers received 
  information from an informant that defendants would be traveling in a vehicle 
  containing illegal drugs and due to the lateness of the hour it would have been 
  impractical to get a search warrant); State v. Frank, 262 S.C. 526, 531-33, 
  205 S.E.2d 827, 830 (1974) (concluding warrantless search of automobile was 
  proper where officer had strong reasons to believe that the automobile was being 
  used in criminal activity and that it very probably contained stolen goods); 
  see also Robinson v. State, 308 A.2d 734, 739-40 (Md. Ct. 
  Spec. App. 1973) (outlining cases holding exigency existed for the search of 
  a vehicle and then removal to police garage).Â Â Â Â Â Â  
The question then becomes whether the warrantless 
  search of the Jeep after it was impounded was permissible under the Fourth Amendment.Â  
  Because the Jeep was at that point immobilized, Weaver asserts that a warrant 
  was required because the exigent circumstances of the mobility of the Jeep were 
  no longer present.
Although there are no South Carolina cases directly 
  on point, the case law from the United States Supreme Court and other jurisdictions 
  supports the admissibility of this evidence despite the lack of a warrant.Â  
  These cases stand for the proposition that if there is probable cause to search 
  a vehicle at the time it is seized this rationale does not disappear merely 
  because the vehicle is taken into police custody.Â  Because a subsequent search 
  would be part of an ongoing criminal investigation, a warrant would not be required.Â  
  See, e.g.,Â  United States v. Johns, 469 U.S. 478, 487 (1985) (holding 
  warrantless search of packages seized three days earlier from trucks which were 
  suspected of being involved in drug smuggling operation was not unreasonable); 
  Florida v. Meyers, 466 U.S. 380, 382 (1984) (finding warrantless search 
  of automobile impounded and in police custody conducted approximately eight 
  hours after valid initial search at the time of defendantâ€™s arrest was proper); 
  Michigan v. Thomas, 458 U.S. 259, 261 (1982) (â€œIt is thus clear that 
  the justification to conduct such a warrantless search does not vanish once 
  the car has been immobilized.â€); Chambers v. Maroney, 399 U.S. 42, 52 
  (1970) (concluding officers had probable cause to conduct second search of automobile 
  at station house); Rabadi v. State, 541 N.E.2d 271, 275 (Ind. 1989) (â€œWhere 
  there is probable cause to believe that a vehicle was used in the commission 
  of a crime and contains evidence, a search of the impounded vehicle may be conducted 
  after the arrest at the police station.â€).Â  
Turning to the facts of the instant case, the State 
  offered evidence that the Jeep was linked to the crime scene and contained evidence 
  when it was impounded.Â  Thus, there was sufficient evidence to support a finding 
  that the officers had probable cause to conduct a warrantless search of the 
  vehicle less than a day after it was impounded.Â  See Ex parte Boyd, 
  542 So. 2d 1276, 1284-86 (Ala. 1989), cert. denied, 493 U.S. 883 (1989) 
  (holding warrantless search of defendantâ€™s automobile four days after impoundment 
  was permissible under requirements of Fourth Amendment and state constitution 
  where officers had probable cause to search vehicle when it was impounded and 
  that probable cause continued between the time of the impoundment and the search); 
  Robinson v. State, 308 A.2d 734, 740-41 (Md. Ct. Spec. App. 1973) (finding 
  officersâ€™ decision to scrape carbon residue from tailpipe of defendantâ€™s vehicle 
  at impoundment lot without a warrant was permissible where officers had probable 
  cause to believe defendant was involved in double murder case and similar carbon 
  residue was found at the crime scene).Â  Moreover, the case law in our state 
  appears to support the admissibility of the evidence.Â  Cf. State v. 
  Lemacks, 275 S.C. 181, 183-84, 268 S.E.2d 285, 286 (1980) (holding police 
  officers were justified in impounding and conducting inventory search which 
  extended to the trunk of the vehicle where vehicle was abandoned and believed 
  to contain stolen goods). 
As a consequence, even if a procedural defect marred 
  the later-acquired warrant, a subsequent failing cannot retroactively undermine 
  the admissibility of previously acquired evidence.Â  Because all the evidence 
  acquired from the Jeep fits within the purview of the automobile exception, 
  Weaver cannot show he was prejudiced by the failure to comply with the ten-day 
  return requirement.Â  Thus, the trial court properly admitted the evidence.
Despite the applicability of the automobile exception, 
  Weaver contends the evidence should have been excluded because Article I, section 
  10 of the South Carolina Constitution afforded him greater protection.Â  Although 
  we agree with Weaver that our state constitution may provide greater protection 
  against unreasonable searches and seizures and unreasonable invasions of privacy, 
  our decision in no way violates or diminishes this protection.Â  See State 
  v. Forrester, 343 S.C. 637, 644, 541 S.E.2d 837, 840 (2001). (â€œ[T]his Court 
  can interpret the state protection against unreasonable searches and seizures 
  in such a way as to provide greater protection than the federal Constitution.â€).Â  
  In analyzing the automobile exception in this case, we have not blindly applied 
  the exception as a blanket provision for the admissibility of evidence.Â  Instead, 
  we have adhered to the probable cause requirement established by our case law 
  that inherently provides protection against unreasonable searches and seizures 
  as well as unreasonable invasions of privacy.Â  See California v. Carney, 
  471 U.S. 386, 394 (1985) (The two requirements for the application of the automobile 
  exception â€œensure that law enforcement officials are not unnecessarily hamstrung 
  in their efforts to detect and prosecute criminal activity, and that the legitimate 
  privacy interests of the public are protected.â€); State v. Lejeune, 576 
  S.E.2d 888, 892 (Ga. 2003) (â€œ[T]he â€˜automobile exceptionâ€™ cases do not hold 
  that a search warrant is never needed to search a car.Â  There is an automobile 
  exception to the search warrant requirement, not an exemption.Â  Otherwise, the 
  Supreme Court of the United States would have held that the police would not, 
  under any circumstances, need to obtain a search warrant for an automobile, 
  provided they have probable cause for the search.â€).
II.
Weaver asserts the trial court erred in 
  admitting the testimony of Lieutenant Ricky Weston that â€œall of the evidence 
  led toâ€ or pointed to Weaver.Â  Because this testimony was based on what witnesses 
  told Lieutenant Weston, Weaver contends it constituted inadmissible hearsay.
During the Stateâ€™s redirect examination of Lieutenant 
  Weston, the following exchange took place:

  
    
      
        Solicitor:
         Didâ€”Let me ask you this, Lieutenant Weston.Â  Why 
  didnâ€™t you do gunshot residue tests on these other people?
      
      
        Weston:
         Well, all evidence that the people they interviewed 
  there at Robâ€™s Place â€“
      
      
        Defense counsel:
        Iâ€™ll object to what these people said, Your 
  Honor.
      
      
        Court: 
         All right.Â  Iâ€™m going to sustain it as such because 
  you did ask him the question, so he can give a reason without saying what the 
  people told you.Â  You can say what his investigation revealed.Â  Thank you.
      
      
        Weston: 
         All the evidence led to Levell Weaver.Â  I didnâ€™t 
  see no blood stain on none of the witnesses that I was talking to at that table.Â  
  All of the witnesses that I talked to led me to believe that --
      
      
        Defense Counsel: 
         Iâ€™ll object to that, Your Honor.
      
      
        Court:
         Overruled.
      
      
        Weston:
         Led me to believe that the subject that we were looking 
  for was the only suspect that really was involved with doing the killing at 
  this crime scene, and I didnâ€™t see no reason to take swabs from those subjects 
  at that table.
      
    
  

â€œâ€˜Hearsayâ€™ is a statement, other than one made 
  by the declarant while testifying at the trial or hearing, offered in evidence 
  to prove the truth of the matter asserted.â€Â  Rule 801(c), SCRE.Â  â€œThe rule against 
  hearsay prohibits the admission of evidence of an out-of-court statement to 
  prove the truth of the matter asserted unless an exception to the rule applies.â€Â  
  Simpkins v. State, 303 S.C. 364, 367, 401 S.E.2d 142, 143 (1991); Rule 
  803, SCRE.Â  
For several reasons we find no error in the admission 
  of the above testimony.Â  First, Lieutenant Weston never repeated statements 
  made to him by individuals at the crime scene.Â  Rather, he testified only to 
  the conclusions he made based on what his investigation had thus far revealed.Â  
  Second, this testimony was in response to the questions asked on cross-examination 
  as to why Lieutenant Weston did not perform a gunshot residue test on everyone 
  at the crime scene.Â  Lieutenant Westonâ€™s testimony was offered to explain this 
  part of his investigation.Â  See State v. Brown, 317 S.C. 55, 63, 
  451 S.E.2d 888, 893-94 (1994) (finding officersâ€™ statements explaining why they 
  began their surveillance of defendantâ€™s apartment were not hearsay); State 
  v. Thompson, 352 S.C. 552, 558, 575 S.E.2d 77, 81 (Ct. App. 2003) (â€œâ€˜[A]n 
  out of court statement is not hearsay if it is offered for the limited purpose 
  of explaining why a government investigation was undertaken.â€™â€ (quoting Brown, 
  317 S.C. at 63, 451 S.E.2d at 894)).Â  Furthermore, Lieutenant Weston did not 
  testify to any specific statements that identified Weaver. 
  [1] Â  Cf. German v. State, 325 S.C. 25, 27-28, 478 S.E.2d 
  687, 688-89 (1996) (holding testimony of undercover drug agent regarding tips 
  that defendant was selling drugs and description of defendant were inadmissible 
  hearsay given the statements specifically referred to defendant).Â  Because this 
  testimony did not constitute hearsay, the trial court did not abuse its discretion 
  in admitting it.Â  See State v. Tucker, 319 S.C. 425, 428, 462 
  S.E.2d 263, 265 (1995), cert. denied, 516 U.S. 1080 (1996) (stating the 
  admission or exclusion of evidence is left to the sound discretion of the trial 
  judge, whose decision will not be reversed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion).
We also note the testimony is cumulative to that 
  given by Investigator Thompson to which Lee made no objection:Â  â€œUpon talking 
  to all of those people, gathered information that we gathered, myself along 
  with Investigator Collins started looking for Mr. Levell Weaver.â€Â Â  Furthermore, 
  Leroy Powell, an eyewitness to the shooting, testified Weaver was the shooter. 
  Â Thus, even if the testimony constituted hearsay, any error in its admission 
  would be harmless.Â  See State v. Haselden, 353 S.C. 190, 197, 
  577 S.E.2d 445, 448-49 (2003) (stating the admission of improper evidence is 
  harmless where the evidence is merely cumulative to other unobjected-to evidence); 
  State v. Kirby, 325 S.C. 390, 396-97, 481 S.E.2d 150, 153 (Ct. App. 1996) 
  (finding even if officerâ€™s testimony regarding information radioed by the police 
  dispatcher constituted hearsay, its admission was harmless given it was cumulative 
  to similar testimony that was admitted without objection).
III.
Weaver argues the trial court erred in not granting 
  a mistrial based on the solicitorâ€™s closing argument. He contends the solicitor 
  impermissibly commented on his right to not testify.Â  
Weaver did not testify during the trial.Â  During 
  closing argument, Weaverâ€™s counsel asked the jury why Weaver would have remained 
  at the scene if he had, in fact, shot the victim:Â  â€œIf hearing [Leroy Powellâ€™s] 
  testimony and then [sic] believe his testimony, Levell shot a fellow some 13 
  times and stayed there until later, does that have the ring of truthfulness 
  to it?Â  Ask yourselves those questions.â€
During his closing argument, the solicitor suggested 
  only Weaver could properly provide an answer to the question posited by his 
  trial counsel:

He was laying there and Levell Weaver was standing down near 
  him or over him she said.Â  He had the gun in his hand and he had blood on him.Â  
  Now, I canâ€™t explain to you why Levell Weaver was there.
Thatâ€™s one of the things [Weaverâ€™s counsel] said, why would 
  Levell Weaver stay around there all that time.Â  Nobody can tell you that except 
  Levell Weaver.
I canâ€™t say why somebody would do something, but we know he 
  was there because Ronald Williams said that he went out there a couple of minutes 
  after the thing, after the shooting occurred, he went out the door.

Weaverâ€™s counsel objected to the argument, contending 
  the solicitor impermissibly commented on Weaverâ€™s decision to not testify during 
  the trial.Â  After a bench conference, the trial court gave a curative instruction, 
  charging the jury the State must prove guilt beyond a reasonable doubt and that 
  a defendant has an absolute right to remain silent, which cannot be considered 
  against him if exercised. 
â€œThe trial court has broad discretion 
  when dealing with the propriety of the solicitorâ€™s argument, including the question 
  of whether to grant a defendantâ€™s mistrial motion.â€Â  State v. Copeland, 
  321 S.C. 318, 324, 468 S.E.2d 620, 624 (1996).Â  â€œThe trial courtâ€™s discretion 
  will not be overturned absent a showing of an abuse of discretion amounting 
  to an error of law that prejudices the defendant.â€Â  Id.Â Â  
Under the United States and South Carolina Constitutions, 
  a criminal defendant has a right to remain silent and to not testify during 
  his trial.Â  U.S. Const. amend. V; S.C. Const. art. I, Â§ 12.Â  As a corollary 
  of this right, a prosecutorial comment, whether direct or indirect, upon a defendantâ€™s 
  failure to testify at trial is constitutionally impermissible.Â  State v. 
  Graddick, 345 S.C. 383, 387, 548 S.E.2d 210, 211-12 (2001); State v. 
  Hawkins, 292 S.C. 418, 423, 357 S.E.2d 10, 13 (1987), overruled on other 
  grounds by State v. Torrence, 305 S.C. 45, 406 S.E.2d 315 (1991).Â  
  â€œWhere the solicitor refers to certain evidence as uncontradicted and the defendant 
  is the only person who could contradict that particular evidence, the statement 
  is viewed as a comment on the defendantâ€™s failure to testify.â€Â  State v. 
  Sweet, 342 S.C. 342, 348, 536 S.E.2d 91, 94 (Ct. App. 2000).
Here, by stating, â€œNobody can tell you that except 
  Levell Weaver,â€ the solicitor plainly implied a question for which only Weaver 
  could supply an answer, and therefore indirectly commented on Weaverâ€™s silence.Â  
  At the same time, although it is improper for a solicitor to indirectly comment 
  on a defendantâ€™s failure to testify, such comments do not necessarily mandate 
  reversal of a conviction.Â  Johnson v. State, 325 S.C. 182, 187, 480 S.E.2d 
  733, 735 (1997).Â  Indeed, a criminal defendant is entitled to a fair trial, 
  not a perfect one.Â  State v. Mizell, 332 S.C. 273, 285, 504 S.E.2d 338, 
  345 (Ct. App. 1998).Â  Thus, as a prerequisite to reversal, Weaver must demonstrate 
  the effect of the solicitorâ€™s closing argument was to deny him a fair trial.Â  
  In making this determination, we must examine the alleged impropriety in light 
  of the entire record.Â  State v. Brown, 333 S.C. 185, 191, 508 S.E.2d 
  38, 41 (Ct. App. 1998); see State v. King, 349 S.C. 142, 159, 
  561 S.E.2d 640, 649 (Ct. App. 2002) (â€œThe test of granting a new trial for alleged 
  improper closing argument is whether the solicitorâ€™s comments so infected the 
  trial with unfairness as to make the resulting conviction a denial of due process.â€).
In full view of the statementâ€™s context, we are 
  forced to conclude that although the comment was improper, reversal is not mandated 
  in this case.Â  First, it was Weaverâ€™s counsel rather than the solicitor that 
  first asked the jury to contemplate why Weaver would have stood over the victim.Â  
  Though it was still improper for the solicitor to point out only Weaver could 
  answer the question posed by his counsel, the egregiousness of the comment is 
  mitigated by the previous comment of Weaverâ€™s counsel.Â  Second, the trial court 
  gave a corrective instruction immediately after the allegedly improper argument.Â  
  â€œGenerally, a trial judgeâ€™s curative instruction is deemed to cure any error.â€Â  
  State v. Simmons, 352 S.C. 342, 354, 573 S.E.2d 856, 863 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  
  Accordingly, we find no error in the trial courtâ€™s denial of Weaverâ€™s motion 
  for mistrial.
CONCLUSION
Based on the foregoing, we find the trial court 
  properly admitted the evidence seized from the Jeep based on the automobile 
  exception to the Fourth Amendment. Additionally, we hold the testimony of Lieutenant 
  Weston regarding his investigation did not constitute inadmissible hearsay.Â  
  Even if it did, any error in its admission would be harmless.Â  Finally, we hold 
  any impropriety in the solicitorâ€™s closing argument did not warrant reversal 
  of Weaverâ€™s convictions.
AFFIRMED. 
HEARN, C.J. and STILWELL, J., concur.

 
   
    [1] Â  At oral argument, Weaverâ€™s appellate counsel asserted this issue 
    was controlled by a recent United States Supreme Court case.Â  Crawford 
    v. Washington, 124 S. Ct. 1354 (2004).Â  In Crawford, the defendant 
    was convicted of first-degree assault with a deadly weapon despite his claim 
    of self-defense.Â  At trial, a tape-recorded statement of defendantâ€™s wife 
    to police officers, in which she implicated her husband in the stabbing, was 
    admitted at trial even though wife did not testify based on the spousal privilege.Â  
    In offering this statement into evidence, the State relied on the hearsay 
    exception for statements against penal interest.Â  Id. at 1358.Â  The 
    Supreme Court reversed the defendantâ€™s conviction, finding the admission of 
    wifeâ€™s testimonial statement violated the Confrontation Clause of the Sixth 
    Amendment.Â  Even though there was an indication of reliability to the statement 
    and it fell within a hearsay exception, the Court believed such statement 
    could only be admitted if the witness was declared unavailable and the defendant 
    had an opportunity to cross-examine the witness prior to trial.Â  Id. 
    at 1374.
  Even if a Confrontation 
    Clause argument was implicit in Weaverâ€™s counselâ€™s objection, the facts of 
    this case are decidedly different than those in Crawford.Â  As previously 
    stated, Lieutenant Weston did not repeat specific statements of witnesses 
    that implicated Weaver as a suspect.Â  Moreover, two of the witnesses, Loretta 
    Scott and Leroy Powell, who identified Weaver as a suspect, testified at trial 
    and were cross-examined by Weaverâ€™s counsel. Therefore, we do not believe 
    Crawford is dispositive.Â
